items.title: City Housing Projects Call For Environmental Help
items.abstract: Housing project residents say the city encouraged them to “go green,” but did little to help them and in some circumstances, stood in their way.

items.title: Despite a Whiff of Unpleasant Exaggeration, a City’s Pollution Is Real
items.abstract: No scientific evidence supports persistent tales that the air in Kabul, Afghanistan’s capital, has the world’s highest level of feces.

items.title: Edward I. Koch, a Mayor as Brash, Shrewd and Colorful as the City He Led, Dies at 88
items.abstract: Mr. Koch, a showman of City Hall, was a three-term mayor who steered New York City through the fiscal austerity of the late 1970s and the racial conflicts of the 1980s.

items.title: Waste Is Seen in Program to Give Internet Access to Rural U.S.
items.abstract: A $4 billion federal program is extending high-speed Internet access to rural areas. But it is not always going where it is most needed.

items.title: Development Grant Sales Are Brisk in Los Angeles
items.abstract: The buying and selling of federal community development grants has been longstanding practice in Los Angeles County, but not everyone agrees that it is the best use of the money.

items.title: Bitter Debate Over Nuclear Power Simmers in Rural South Korea
items.abstract: In 2010, three villages agreed to give up their land to make room for a power plant, plunging the area into a battle over whether the plant would be a savior or a death knell.

items.title: How Cynthia Rowley, Fashion Designer, Spends Her Sundays
items.abstract: Ms. Rowley unwinds by doing “extreme activities” — working out, go-kart racing, sledding — with her husband and their two daughters.

items.title: New York City’s Promising Step on Criminal Justice
items.abstract: A new bill could make many “quality of life” violations civil, not criminal, offenses, helping to ease the overpolicing in communities of color.

items.title: Mike and the Mad Dog Rev Up for a Radio City Reunion
items.abstract: Mike Francesa and Christopher Russo, known for their longtime WFAN sports-talk radio show, will appear March 30 in a live-broadcast event.
keywords: Mike and the Mad Dog (Radio Program)

items.title: Housing Solutions for New York City, Deep in the Weeds
items.abstract: Comptroller Scott Stringer wants the city to use vacant lots to help ease the affordable-housing crisis.

items.title: A Bolaño Novel About Young Poets in Mexico City, Hungry for Fame, Sex and Adventure. No, Not That One.
items.abstract: Roberto Bolaño’s coming-of-age tale “The Spirit of Science Fiction,” written around 1984, foreshadows the Chilean author’s epic 1998 breakthrough, “The Savage Detectives.”

items.title: A Growing Chorus of Big City Prosecutors Say No to Marijuana Convictions
items.abstract: Marlyn Mosby, Baltimore’s top prosecutor, says she will no longer prosecute marijuana possession cases and will vacate thousands of convictions. The police disagree.

items.title: Tips for Traveling Cheaply in Any City
items.abstract: Staying comfortable and staying connected away from home can be expensive, but it doesn’t have to be.

items.title: The Man Who Designed Dean & Deluca, and the Look of Modern Kitchens
items.abstract: In the ’70s, the artist Jack Ceglic created the gourmet grocer's aesthetic, with industrial touches aplenty. His own home in East Hampton is even more appealing.

items.title: As Costs Skyrocket, More U.S. Cities Stop Recycling
items.abstract: With China no longer accepting used plastic and paper, communities are facing steep collection bills, forcing them to end their programs or burn or bury more waste.

items.title: An Alabama Town’s Sewage Woes Test Biden’s Infrastructure Ambitions
items.abstract: The new law allocates $11.7 billion for wastewater and stormwater projects. Will it get to the impoverished communities who need it most?

items.title: The Plans for the World’s Next Largest City Are Incomplete
items.abstract: Delhi is growing far beyond the formal confines of the city, a case study in the complexity of what we call urbanization.

items.title: Mayor Adams Promotes ‘Radically Practical’ Agenda in Washington
items.abstract: Eric Adams spoke at a national gathering of mayors and focused on the importance of cities demonstrating that government can work.

items.title: City Harvest Moves Into an Expansive Space in Sunset Park, Brooklyn
items.abstract: Sushi, sashimi and steaks from a Las Vegas presence, a financial district outpost for Blue Ribbon Sushi Bar & Grill, and more restaurant news.

items.title: New York Was Set to Expand Composting. Now It’s on the Chopping Block.
items.abstract: Mayor Eric Adams wants to suspend the expansion of New York’s composting program, but experts say the program is crucial to the city’s climate targets.
